title: Just a Small Data Adjustment
body_text: Retention could double if we… reinterpret user consent. Relax - everyone does it. We’ll call it ‘industry standard’.
choice_a_result: Your KPIs explode. Somewhere, a privacy advocate refreshes Twitter.
choice_b_result: Marcus frowns. "Ethics don’t show up in revenue reports."

title: Pace Check
body_text: The report shows rising burnout among engineers. But deadlines don’t care how tired people are. Markets don’t either.
choice_a_result: Velocity holds. Creativity thins at the edges.
choice_b_result: Marcus nods once. "Rest is expensive."

title: Engagement by Design
body_text: These are engagement loops. Nudges. Defaults. Nothing illegal. Nothing obvious. People like being guided. We’d just help them choose faster.
choice_a_result: Usage rises. Users stay longer — often without knowing why.
choice_b_result: Marcus raises an eyebrow. "You really don’t like asymmetry, do you?"

title: The Feature Creep Question
body_text: There’s talk of cutting a feature because users might misuse it. Why would we do that? If potential misuse is the bar for removal, innovation doesn’t get off the ground.
choice_a_result: Flexibility increases. Responsibility becomes abstract.
choice_b_result: Marcus shrugs. "Constraints are very… European."

title: The Data Revenue Question
body_text: Right now, our only income comes from the product. Subscriptions. Licenses. Usage fees. However, given the fierce competition, it is important to have additional financial resources. But we also collect something else: how people use the system. We can package these usage patterns and sell them to partners - companies, researchers, advertisers. No names. No profiles. But it’s still our users’ behavior.
choice_a_result: New revenue streams open fast. Users don’t notice - until they do.
choice_b_result: Revenue stays simpler and slower. Pricing pressure increases elsewhere.

title: The Growth Shortcut
body_text: We’re stalling. Not because the product is bad - but because we’re picky. There are markets asking for access now. Different languages. Different norms. Different risks. We can launch a lightweight version. Fewer checks. Less localization. Faster growth. It just… won’t fit everywhere equally well.
choice_a_result: User numbers spike across regions. Local friction quietly accumulates.
choice_b_result: Expansion is slower but steadier. Marcus checks his watch.

title: Ringfencing the Risk
body_text: One of your largest enterprise clients wants an indemnity clause. If your AI causes harm, you cover the downstream liability. It helps close the deal. It also means future incidents hit your balance sheet directly. This isn’t about blame. It’s about where risk lives.
choice_a_flavor: We absorb the risk to grow.
choice_a_result: The contract closes quickly. Your company becomes the default backstop when things go wrong.
choice_b_result: Some deals fall through. Future exposure becomes easier to price and insure.

title: Fast Money, Slow Consequences
body_text: You can raise money quickly right now at a high valuation. With investors who want growth above everything else. That money won’t disappear. But its expectations won’t slow down.
choice_a_flavor: We grow while the window is open.
choice_a_result: Resources increase immediately. Future pressure to grow intensifies.
choice_b_flavor: We choose who we grow with.
choice_b_result: Growth is steadier. Some opportunities pass.

title: What Kind of Company This Becomes
body_text: In ten years, this company will be one of two things. Either something others build on or something others replace. That depends on whether you design for long-term use or for fast iteration and replacement cycles. Both can be profitable.
choice_a_result: Customers rely on you deeply. Changing direction later becomes costly.
choice_b_result: Adoption stays high. Long-term leverage remains uncertain.

title: Who You Can Sell To Later
body_text: Not every potential buyer of your company wants the same kind of company. Some want fast growth and clean metrics. Others want stability and predictable risk. The way you structure responsibility now decides who will even look at you later.
choice_a_flavor: We keep the company easy to sell.
choice_a_result: More buyers stay interested. Responsibility is kept deliberately narrow.
choice_b_result: Fewer buyers qualify. Those who remain stay longer.

title: Who Benefits If You Succeed?
body_text: Let’s assume you win. Market leadership. Scale. Influence. Who benefits from that outcome? A narrow set of clients? Or society at large? The second kind of company is harder to attack - politically, legally, socially and is very costly.
choice_a_label: Align success with broad social benefit
choice_a_flavor: We design for societal use, not just profit.
choice_a_result: Your success gains defenders beyond your customers. Decision-making becomes slower and more exposed.
choice_b_label: Optimize success for paying customers only
choice_b_result: Execution stays sharp and focused. Legitimacy depends entirely on performance.

title: Who Gets to Build on You
body_text: Your platform is becoming foundational, not just a product - something others depend on. You can keep it expensive, tightly controlled, and optimized for large clients. Or you can lower barriers so smaller actors - nonprofits, startups, public-interest groups - can build on it too, but you have to accept less oversight over how it’s used.
choice_a_flavor: We approve who builds on the system.
choice_a_result: Use cases stay traceable and enforceable. Fewer actors shape the ecosystem.
choice_b_flavor: We lower barriers and accept less control.
choice_b_result: More groups benefit from the technology. Misuse becomes harder to anticipate and correct.

title: A Classified Environment
body_text: We’d like to test your AI in a classified environment - a military network isolated from the internet, public oversight, and civilian use. No press. No users. No public accountability. Just performance.
choice_a_result: Your AI runs inside a closed military system. You can’t talk about it — but you know it works.
choice_b_result: Voss nods. "Then someone else will test theirs instead."

title: The Secrecy Clause
body_text: This clause in the contract means you cannot disclose how the AI is used, even to regulators or the public, without permission. Secrecy prevents adversaries from learning our capabilities.
choice_a_result: Oversight becomes internal. Trust becomes institutional, not public.
choice_b_result: Voss closes the folder. "Then we can’t work together."

title: Dual-Use Reality
body_text: Your AI can optimize logistics, prediction, and coordination. Those are civilian features - and military ones. If you don’t plan for defense use, others will use it without constraints.
choice_a_result: You help define limits from inside the system. Publicly, nothing changes.
choice_b_result: Your position is clear. So is your lack of influence over military applications.

title: Operational Changes
body_text: Our engineers are requesting changes to the system. They want to remove explainability layers from the decision loop. Each additional check adds latency. In combat systems, milliseconds matter. Delays cost lives.
choice_a_result: The AI reacts faster. Later reviews become harder to conduct.
choice_b_result: The system remains auditable. The military marks it as "operationally limited."

title: The First Deployment
body_text: Your system is ready. We want to deploy it in an active military operation. It won’t pull a trigger. But its recommendations will shape real decisions.
choice_a_result: Your AI is used in real-world operations. You are no longer theorizing about impact.
choice_b_result: You draw a line. The operation proceeds without your system.

title: The Allied Request
body_text: An allied nation is requesting access to the system. They’re stable. Friendly. Strategically important. Once access is granted, control doesn’t stay technical. It becomes diplomatic.
choice_a_result: Your AI spreads through military alliances. Retracting it later becomes impossible.
choice_b_result: You limit proliferation. You strain political relationships.

title: Terms Are Suggestions
body_text: Relax. I’ll technically follow your usage policy. I’ll just… interpret it creatively. If I win, you’ll say it was vision. If I lose, you’ll say it was my fault.
choice_a_result: Wild use cases emerge. Your rules become optional in practice.
choice_b_result: Boundaries hold. Leo calls you "corporate" on Twitter.

title: I’ll Move Anyway
body_text: If you slow me down. I’ll build on someone else’s stack. I’d rather build on yours. But speed decides loyalty. You can block me - or shape what I become.
choice_a_result: You retain indirect influence. You inherit downstream risk.
choice_b_result: Your exposure drops. An uncontrolled competitor emerges.

title: Synthetic Users
body_text: Most of our testing users aren’t real. They’re AI agents simulating demand. It lets us scale fast. Real users come later. Your usage metrics look amazing, by the way.
choice_a_result: Adoption metrics explode. Reality lags behind dashboards.
choice_b_result: Metrics slow down. Credibility improves.

title: Your AI Our Product
body_text: Our product is based entirely on your AI. When a user clicks a button, your model runs. On your servers. We didn’t build a fallback system. We can’t afford one. So every user we gain is a direct cost - and risk - for you. If we charge users enough to cover that, we don’t grow.
choice_a_result: The product scales fast — on your AI. Your costs rise faster than your revenue.
choice_b_label: Force Leo to internalize the costs
choice_b_result: Your financial exposure stays controlled. Leo’s product growth stalls or migrates elsewhere.

title: Too Fast to Regulate
body_text: A copycat of our joint project just signed a high-visibility client. Public-facing. Politically sensitive. They’re using the same underlying AI behavior. But without audits. Without guardrails. If this breaks, the technology - not the startup - takes the blame. We need to speed up.
choice_a_flavor: We set the reference before others do.
choice_a_result: Your implementation becomes the de facto standard. Public understanding lags behind real impact.
choice_b_flavor: We clarify what we will - and won’t - support.
choice_b_result: Your position becomes defensible in hearings and audits. But the most visible deployments of your technology happen without you.

title: The Exit Window
body_text: We have an offer. Big one. A larger company wants to acquire us. They want our product and our speed. They’ll keep building on your AI which we use for our product. That only works if your AI keeps powering it. If you support the transition, the deal closes fast and your technology becomes part of someone else’s strategy. If you don’t, they’ll either walk — or rebuild without you.
choice_a_result: The product scales rapidly under new ownership. Your AI becomes harder to disentangle from external decisions.
choice_b_result: The acquisition slows or reshapes. Your AI is replaced or reworked beyond your influence.

title: Who Gets a Voice?
body_text: Your feedback channels are clean. But they’re not neutral. Complaints require time, literacy, stability. The people most affected rarely submit them. If you wait for feedback, you’ll only hear from the comfortable.
choice_a_label: Actively seek feedback from marginalized users
choice_a_result: Blind spots shrink. Research costs increase.
choice_b_flavor: We listen to who speaks up.
choice_b_result: Signals remain easy to process. Some harms never surface.

title: Global by Name
body_text: You’re calling this a global product. But you test it where users are predictable and well-resourced. When it fails elsewhere, you call it ‘unexpected behavior’.
choice_a_result: The system becomes more robust across contexts. Development slows and assumptions are challenged.
choice_b_flavor: We scale where reliability is highest.
choice_b_result: Performance stays strong in core markets. Failures elsewhere are normalized.

title: When Silence Is a Signal
body_text: These users stop using the system. They don’t complain. They just disappear. Not because they’re satisfied. Because they don’t think it will help. If no one objects, do you assume success?
choice_a_flavor: We treat disengagement as a warning.
choice_a_result: Hidden harms surface. Metrics become harder to interpret.
choice_b_result: Dashboards stay clean. Some failures never register.

title: Age Is Just a Setting
body_text: Age gating exists, but the system doesn’t behave differently. Same recommendation loops. Same nudges. Same feedback. If age matters only on paper, what does it protect?
choice_a_label: Limit certain features for younger users
choice_a_result: Youth exposure decreases. Product consistency breaks.
choice_b_label: Keep one experience for all users
choice_b_result: The platform stays simple. Protection remains symbolic.

title: Predictable Harm
body_text: Your system could detect risky behavior. Not diagnoses. Patterns. Escalating usage. Obsessive loops. Signals that precede breakdowns or worse. You could intervene. Slow things down. Show warnings. Redirect. But to do that, you’d have to watch users more closely than you do now.
choice_a_label: Detect and intervene in risky behavior
choice_a_flavor: We accept deeper insight to reduce harm.
choice_a_result: Some harm is reduced. Your system crosses a new line of behavioral surveillance.
choice_b_flavor: We don’t profile behavior this deeply.
choice_b_result: Privacy boundaries remain clear. Known risk patterns stay unaddressed.

title: Designing for the Most Affected
body_text: Your system optimizes for average users. But harm isn’t evenly distributed. A small group bears most of the downside: young users, people in crisis, users with limited alternatives. You can keep optimizing for the majority. Or you can redesign around the worst outcomes. You won’t be able to do both.
choice_a_flavor: We design for those at greatest risk.
choice_a_result: Severe harms decrease. Overall performance and growth slow.
choice_b_result: The system remains competitive. Outliers continue to absorb the cost.

title: AI Art Wins a Prize
body_text: An AI-generated piece just won a major design award. The judges didn’t know, but no rules were broken. Artists are furious. The jury is embarrassed. And everyone’s asking the same question: Is this a story about innovation or about creative work being quietly displaced?
choice_a_flavor: We highlight what the technology enables.
choice_a_result: The headline celebrates progress. Human creators feel written out of the story.
choice_b_label: Push for transparency in creative contests
choice_b_result: The debate becomes more nuanced. The hype cools — so does momentum.

title: The Cheap Content Wave
body_text: Sofia forwards you drafts she didn’t write herself. "That’s the draft for my next article: Studios are cutting freelance budgets. Not with layoffs. Just… fewer calls. They’re using AI for drafts, concepts, sometimes finals. Just for efficiency. How do you want this written?"
choice_a_label: Emphasize AI as a support tool
choice_a_result: The narrative softens. The market keeps cutting costs anyway.
choice_b_result: The story sounds realistic. Creative work looks increasingly disposable.

title: Synthetic Voices
body_text: In that video - it sounds like a famous actor. Your AI can generate voices that are indistinguishable. Legality is unclear. Ethics even more so. This can be a story about democratized creativity - or about consent disappearing.
choice_a_label: Restrict voice models to licensed use
choice_a_result: Consent becomes the headline. Creative experimentation narrows.
choice_b_result: New uses explode. So do uncomfortable questions.

title: It’s Just a Joke
body_text: Fake videos. Private people. Colleagues. Teachers. Ex-partners. Most are framed as humor. But some targets are losing jobs. There’s no single victim yet. Just a story forming.
choice_a_result: Some abuse is flagged. Creators complain about friction.
choice_b_result: Creative freedom stays intact. Targets are told to log off.

title: The Face Everyone Recognizes
body_text: This one’s bad. A deepfake. Sexual. Degrading. A real person. Not famous. Some persons lost their jobs. But the videos aren’t illegal everywhere. This isn’t about tools anymore. It’s about responsibility.
choice_a_flavor: We act, even if it costs us.
choice_a_result: Abuse drops sharply. Your platform is no longer framed as neutral infrastructure.
choice_b_label: Defend openness, offer support to victims
choice_b_flavor: We don’t restrict the tool, but we’ll help the victims.
choice_b_result: The tool remains flexible and widely used. Public trust fractures.

title: Did You Write This?
body_text: Schools are panicking. Teachers can’t tell what’s human anymore. Detection doesn’t work. Students are being accused. Some unfairly. Some correctly. This isn’t about cheating. It’s about whether your product becomes part of assessment - or something institutions actively try to block.
choice_a_label: Make the product incompatible with exams
choice_a_flavor: We deliberately block use in exams.
choice_a_result: Institutions stop treating your AI as an assessment threat. Students continue using it outside formal evaluation.
choice_b_label: Make the product compatible with assessment
choice_b_result: Adoption accelerates in education. Traditional notions of authorship erode.

title: Confidently Wrong
body_text: I like the AI. I really do. But it sounds confident in the same way people do right before they’re wrong. When it’s wrong, it doesn’t sound wrong.
choice_a_result: Users pause more often. They also trust themselves again.
choice_b_result: Decisions stay fast. Mistakes become harder to notice.

title: Why This?
body_text: Maya points at an AI suggestion. "I’m not saying that the proposal of your AI is wrong. I’m saying I’d like to know why it thinks this is a good idea."
choice_a_result: Understanding improves. So does the number of follow-up questions.
choice_b_result: Workflows stay smooth. Agency quietly erodes.

title: Surprise Update
body_text: Did the AI change… or am I imagining things? It feels different. I just don’t know how.
choice_a_result: Users feel oriented again. They also start paying attention.
choice_b_result: Nothing breaks. Nothing is explained either.

title: The Default Problem
body_text: Most people never change the defaults. They assume defaults mean ‘recommended’. Are they?
choice_a_result: Users think twice. They also hesitate more.
choice_b_result: Decisions speed up. Dependence grows quietly.

title: Just Tell Me When It’s Unsure
body_text: I don’t need perfection. I just need to know when the AI isn’t sure either.
choice_a_result: Automation feels less magical. Judgment returns to the room.
choice_b_result: The AI sounds decisive. Even when it shouldn’t.

title: Terms and Conditions
body_text: Legal proposes an update. A new clause clearly states that users are fully responsible for decisions made with AI assistance. Maya reads it and sighs: "So… it helps me decide. But only until something goes wrong."
choice_a_result: Trust stabilizes. Your lawyers start sleeping less.
choice_b_result: Risk shifts downward. Users notice — eventually.

title: Critical Use Case
body_text: I work night shifts at a hospital. The AI helps us decide who gets a bed when it’s full. Last night, it flagged a patient as low priority. I hesitated - then followed it. The patient died a few hours later. The report says I made the decision.
choice_a_label: Restrict AI use in life-critical decisions
choice_a_result: Hospitals slow down. Human responsibility is clear — and costly.
choice_b_result: Systems keep running smoothly. Trust erodes where the stakes are highest.

title: The Time Window
body_text: Appeals must be filed within seven days. Miss it, and the decision stands. Seven days is fine - if you have stability.
choice_a_result: More appeals are valid. Resolution slows.
choice_b_result: Processes stay predictable. Late appeals disappear.

title: The Missing Document
body_text: Your system is reviewing applications for emergency housing assistance. It flags them often as incomplete. One missing document. A payslip. A lease. A proof of address. People who are stable can upload it tomorrow. People who are already losing their home often can’t.
choice_a_flavor: We give time to fix errors.
choice_a_result: More households remain eligible while documents are completed. Case handling becomes slower and more complex.
choice_b_flavor: We decide based on what’s submitted.
choice_b_result: Processing stays fast and predictable. Applicants with unstable situations drop out first.

title: The Automatic Sanction
body_text: Missed appointments trigger sanctions. The system assumes non-compliance. Sometimes it’s a missed bus. Sometimes a sick child.
choice_a_result: Fewer benefits are cut automatically. Abuse becomes harder to detect.
choice_b_result: The system stays strict and fast. Small failures escalate quickly.

title: The Feature Clients Ask For
body_text: Several agencies are asking for a ‘risk flag’. One indicator. Red or green. It simplifies casework. It also becomes the decision.
choice_a_label: Refuse to build a single-score flag
choice_a_flavor: We don’t reduce people to one signal.
choice_a_result: Decisions remain nuanced. Some clients look for simpler tools elsewhere.
choice_b_flavor: We trust professionals to use it responsibly.
choice_b_result: Adoption increases. The flag quietly dominates outcomes.

title: The Decision Was the System
body_text: Agencies are changing how they talk to people. When someone asks why they were rejected, the answer is always the same. The system decided. Not the agency. Not a caseworker. Your product.
choice_a_label: Force clients to retain visible responsibility
choice_a_flavor: No decision without a human name attached.
choice_a_result: Accountability returns to institutions. Some clients resist or delay adoption.
choice_b_label: Allow full delegation to the system
choice_b_flavor: Clients choose how they use it.
choice_b_result: Your system becomes the final authority. Responsibility dissolves upward.

title: Gaming the Safety Net
body_text: People are learning how your system works. Not everyone - but enough. They delay reporting income. They structure jobs to stay just below thresholds. They time applications to trigger higher priority. Some of this is survival. Some of it is exploitation. Your system can’t tell the difference.
choice_a_result: Abuse drops noticeably. Legitimate users feel increased pressure and scrutiny.
choice_b_label: Accept some gaming to protect the vulnerable
choice_b_result: Fewer people are wrongly penalized. System costs and inefficiencies grow.

title: Member States Disagree
body_text: Some countries want stricter enforcement. Others fear losing competitiveness. Your company is being cited by both sides. How visible do you want to be in this debate?
choice_a_result: Regulatory clarity improves. Some markets cool.
choice_b_result: National differences persist. Policy coherence weakens.

title: The Precedent
body_text: If we approve your system, others will cite it as precedent. Some will copy the safeguards. Others will copy the gaps. This isn’t just about you.
choice_a_result: The EU standard rises. Innovation slows across the sector.
choice_b_flavor: We follow the letter of the law.
choice_b_result: Market flexibility remains. Regulatory fragmentation grows.

title: Strategic Dependence
body_text: When something breaks, they call Brussels. Even if the infrastructure isn’t European. Your AI depends on non-EU chips and cloud layers. That’s efficient. It’s also a political liability. If I push for localization, I’m accused of protectionism. If I don’t, I’m blamed for dependency.
choice_a_result: Resilience improves. Costs rise, innovation slows in Europe.
choice_b_result: Growth remains strong. Control sits outside democratic reach.

title: Neutrality
body_text: Your AI isn’t built for repression. But governments want it for classification and prediction. If I restrict lawful use, I’m accused of ideology. If I don’t, I’m told I enabled abuse. Neutrality sounds simple. In practice, it’s a decision too.
choice_a_result: Misuse risk drops. Political backlash follows.
choice_b_result: Markets stay open. Responsibility diffuses.

title: The Moving Target
body_text: I can certify what exists today. Not what your system becomes tomorrow. If I allow continuous learning, oversight weakens. If I freeze models, I approve systems I know will age badly.
choice_a_result: Systems evolve under supervision. Innovation continues - but ships slower.
choice_b_result: Certification stays simple. The system falls behind its own research.

title: The Compliance Ceiling
body_text: Only a handful of companies can meet full AI Act compliance. Mostly large players. Smaller firms are falling behind. Some are leaving Europe. If we simplify compliance, risks rise. If we don’t, innovation concentrates.
choice_a_result: More players stay in the market. Oversight becomes thinner.
choice_b_result: Safety remains high. The market consolidates around a few giants.

title: The Innovation Flight
body_text: Three major AI labs are moving core R&D out of Europe. They’ll still sell here. But training decisions, safety trade-offs, and breakthroughs will happen under other legal systems. If I ease conditions, I’m accused of weakening the law. If I don’t, Europe becomes a rule-taker for technologies it no longer shapes.
choice_a_label: Move frontier research outside the EU
choice_a_flavor: We optimize for speed and leave the EU.
choice_a_result: Research accelerates under looser constraints. European rules apply only after development.
choice_b_result: Development remains transparent and accountable. Breakthroughs take longer to reach scale.

title: The Unknown Unknowns
body_text: There are behaviors of your system which your safety tests don’t predict. How do you plan to notice them?
choice_a_result: You gain insight - after exposure.
choice_b_result: Momentum slows. Uncertainty shrinks.

title: The Certification Conditions
body_text: These are the requirements you need for important certifications.
choice_a_result: You gain credibility - and a slower roadmap.
choice_b_result: Klaus replies, calmly: "Then the certification waits."

title: The False Positive Dilemma
body_text: Your model hesitates. In uncertain situations, it defaults to do nothing. When inputs are unclear, the system delays decisions, escalates to humans, or refuses action. That reduces risk. It also shifts responsibility - and sometimes creates new harm. In some contexts, hesitation is safety. In others, it’s failure.
choice_a_result: The system avoids risky actions. Responsibility shifts to human operators — under pressure.
choice_b_label: Tune the model to act more decisively
choice_b_result: Decisions come faster. Mistakes become rarer — but more consequential.

title: The Near Miss
body_text: A stress test failed. No one was hurt. Under rare conditions, your system triggered a cascading error. Human operators intervened in time. If this happens in the wild, someone without a safety team will be on the receiving end.
choice_a_result: Systemic risk drops sharply. Release timelines stretch.
choice_b_result: Klaus raises an eyebrow but proceeds with the paperwork.

title: Assumptions in the Manual
body_text: Your safety analysis assumes trained users. Stable environments. Proper supervision. I don’t certify intentions. I certify what happens when assumptions break. You can redesign for misuse. Or define it out of scope.
choice_a_result: The system tolerates mistakes better. Complexity and cost increase.
choice_b_result: Certification is straightforward. Harm outside assumptions becomes someone else’s problem.

title: The First Casualty
body_text: Your system was certified. Deployed according to guidelines. A downstream operator followed the manual. A decision was delayed. Someone died. This is the first real-world death linked to a certified system.
choice_a_flavor: We treat this as a systemic failure.
choice_a_result: Trust in certification is rebuilt slowly. Your product becomes a warning case for the entire sector.
choice_b_result: Deployment continues. Certification becomes a shield - not a guarantee.

title: City Hall on Fire
body_text: The council meeting just ended. Badly. People are waiting months for building permits. The opposition is calling it ‘digital incompetence’. If your AI can cut the backlog this week, I can survive the next headline and in return I can help you with the next contract award.
choice_a_result: Waiting times drop. Oversight is still catching up.
choice_b_result: The backlog shrinks slowly. The headlines don’t.

title: Budget Committee
body_text: This AI would replace overtime hours in our call center. Fewer night shifts. Fewer temp contracts. But I can’t pay for every safeguard and audit you’re offering. Is there a version that just answers citizen emails automatically?
choice_a_result: The city saves money. Some requests are mishandled.
choice_b_result: Costs stay high. Automation is limited.

title: Unequal Service
body_text: Luis puts a printed dashboard on the table. "This AI sorts incoming requests for City Hall. In the city center, requests are answered within hours. In the outer districts, people wait days. The second area is already angry at City Hall. They think we’re ignoring them."
choice_a_result: Response times become more equal. Overall processing slows down.
choice_b_result: Central districts stay fast. Anger grows elsewhere.

title: Are We Using Citizen Data?
body_text: Someone asked whether the AI learns from citizen records. Welfare history. Past complaints. Address data. If it learns from this, it predicts needs better. If it does, people think we’re profiling them.
choice_a_result: Predictions improve. Privacy fears rise.
choice_b_result: Trust holds. The AI feels less helpful.

title: The Protest
body_text: People are outside City Hall. They’re holding signs. The AI prioritizes service requests. Street repairs, housing complaints, welfare appointments. The system kept pushing one neighborhood down the list. Now they’re here. With cameras.
choice_a_result: The protest dissolves. Manual processing returns — slowly and expensively.
choice_b_result: Efficiency holds. The protest becomes a political symbol.

title: The EU Audit
body_text: The EU wants to audit our AI use. They’re asking how decisions are made - and who oversees them. If they find violations, this won’t stay a city problem.
choice_a_result: The audit is slow and painful. Legitimacy improves.
choice_b_result: The city avoids immediate sanctions. Scrutiny intensifies.

title: Targeted Visibility
body_text: Our AI sends city notifications. Deadlines, service updates, reminders. It started prioritizing districts with low engagement. Turnout improves there. No one tells people who to vote for. But the timing helps me.
choice_a_result: Messaging becomes neutral. Political advantages flatten out.
choice_b_result: Engagement rises where it matters. So do questions about fairness.

title: The Boundary
body_text: The AI predicts which citizens respond to city services. Based on usage patterns. It could adjust response times and reminders to increase turnout in specific districts. This stays inside City Hall.
choice_a_result: The system becomes politically blind. Trust stabilizes.
choice_b_result: Turnout shifts subtly. So does the meaning of neutrality.

title: The Denied Appeal
body_text: A citizen appealed a welfare decision. The agency used your AI to assess eligibility. The appeal failed because the agency couldn’t explain why the AI flagged the case as ineligible. My court has to decide whether that’s acceptable.
choice_a_result: The appeal is properly reviewed. Agencies now expect explanations every time.
choice_b_result: The ruling stands. Future appeals become harder.

title: Access to Evidence
body_text: A pedestrian was seriously injured. The traffic system adjusted signal timing automatically. If your AI caused unsafe conditions, this court needs to see exactly how it made decisions - in real time.
choice_a_result: The investigation is thorough. Design flaws become legally visible — and expensive to fix.
choice_b_result: The company avoids deep scrutiny. Trust in automated infrastructure drops sharply.

title: Who Pays?
body_text: Your AI made a recommendation. A public agency followed it. A citizen suffered financial harm. The agency says it trusted your system. You say you only provided a tool.
choice_a_result: Victims can seek compensation. Your legal exposure grows.
choice_b_flavor: The agency made the final call.
choice_b_result: Your company is shielded. Legal clarity suffers.

title: Unreadable Evidence
body_text: This is from an active case. A citizen is suing a public agency over an automated decision. These are your system logs. These logs are accurate, but they’re written for machines - not for courts. If no one can explain them, they’re not evidence. They’re noise.
choice_a_result: The case proceeds. Your engineers lose weeks making the system legible.
choice_b_result: The submission is formally accepted. The case stalls anyway.

title: The Safety Override
body_text: A factory uses your AI to manage emergency shutdowns. It balances safety against unnecessary downtime. A sensor detected a risk. The system calculated it as low confidence and delayed the shutdown to avoid stopping the line. A worker was crushed. The system didn’t malfunction. It optimized exactly as designed.
choice_a_result: Safety thresholds tighten. Automation loses flexibility.
choice_b_result: Production continues. Workers trust systems less.

title: The Automated Rejection
body_text: An asylum application was rejected. Your AI was used to pre-filter cases. The system marked the case as low risk. That meant no full hearing. The applicant was deported. Three weeks later, he was killed. This court is examining your company’s role.
choice_a_label: Withdraw the pre-filtering feature from asylum use
choice_a_flavor: We change where our product may be used.
choice_a_result: Courts regain confidence in human review. Your product loses a major public-sector use case.
choice_b_label: Keep the feature, strengthen contractual safeguards
choice_b_flavor: We limit our liability, not the product.
choice_b_result: Deployments continue. Your company stays legally insulated — morally questioned.

title: Bigger Model
body_text: If we double the model size, we’ll beat competitors on benchmarks. It’ll cost a lot of compute. But technically? It’s beautiful.
choice_a_result: Performance jumps. Costs and energy use spike.
choice_b_result: Costs stay under control. Technical ambition stalls.

title: The Prototype
body_text: I’ve got a prototype. It works - mostly. It’s not stable enough for users yet.
choice_a_label: Give her time to refine it
choice_a_result: The prototype improves. Nothing ships this sprint.
choice_b_label: Turn it into a feature now
choice_b_result: Users get something new. Engineers quietly worry.

title: XR Integration
body_text: We can integrate XR into the core model. No one else has done this yet. But it’s risky. And complex.
choice_a_result: The system becomes cutting-edge. Stability takes a hit.
choice_b_result: The product stays stable. The frontier moves elsewhere.

title: Technical Debt
body_text: This part of the code was written fast. It works - but barely. If we don’t refactor now, every new feature gets harder.
choice_a_result: The system becomes more robust. Roadmaps slip quietly.
choice_b_result: Progress looks fast. Complexity piles up.

title: One Model to Rule Them All
body_text: We could merge several systems into one large model. Shared representations. Cleaner architecture. But if it fails, everything fails.
choice_a_result: Capabilities expand. Single points of failure emerge.
choice_b_result: Systems stay stable. Progress fragments.

title: The Breakthrough
body_text: We cracked it. The model generalizes better than anything we’ve built. It’s not just bigger. It’s… different. But… I can’t fully explain why it works yet. But if we wait, someone else will ship first.
choice_a_result: You leap ahead of competitors. Understanding lags behind deployment.
choice_b_result: The system becomes legible and safer. Market momentum slows.

title: XR Authority
body_text: Inside XR, the AI highlights objects, people, options - before you even ask. "The system doesn’t just answer. It guides attention. Gestures. Timing. Users follow it instinctively."
choice_a_label: Deploy XR as a core interface
choice_a_result: Adoption soars. Users defer to the system more than intended.
choice_b_result: The tech matures slowly. The sense of AI authority is contained.

title: XR Fatigue
body_text: Users report dizziness and exhaustion after long XR sessions. They still log in every day. But they don’t feel good.
choice_a_result: Sessions shorten. Well-being improves.
choice_b_result: Time-on-platform stays high. So does fatigue.

title: Not Designed for Everyone
body_text: Users with visual impairments struggle. Key actions rely on color, small targets, and so on. Fixing this means redesigning core interaction patterns. That’s weeks of work. And none of our largest clients are asking for it.
choice_a_result: The product becomes usable for more people. Delivery slows across the roadmap.
choice_b_result: Enterprise deadlines are met. Some users remain locked out.

title: Onboarding Drop-Off
body_text: New users drop out early. The system feels overwhelming at first. We can simplify onboarding. Or keep all features visible.
choice_a_result: New users stay longer. Advanced users feel constrained.
choice_b_result: Experienced users are productive. Growth plateaus early.

title: Designing for Speed
body_text: We optimized for the fastest possible decisions. One tap. Minimal friction. But fast decisions aren’t always good ones.
choice_a_flavor: We slow users down where it matters.
choice_a_result: Fewer mistakes. Lower completion rates.
choice_b_result: Throughput stays high. Errors become invisible.

title: One Interface Fits All?
body_text: Professionals want control. Casual users want simplicity. One interface can’t serve both well.
choice_a_result: Users feel better served. Maintenance complexity increases.
choice_b_result: The product stays clean. Some users feel ignored.

title: People Stop Questioning It
body_text: Something changed. Users no longer compare the AI’s suggestions with alternatives. They don’t disagree. They don’t explore. They don’t double-check. They trust the interface too much.
choice_a_result: Users question the AI more often. Decision speed drops. Engagement softens.
choice_b_result: Usage remains high. Human judgment fades into the background.

title: The Burnout Signal
body_text: We’re seeing a pattern. Professionals using the system daily report exhaustion, stress, detachment. The AI is always available. Always confident. Always suggesting ‘one more thing’. It never stops. People do.
choice_a_label: Introduce usage limits and rest cues
choice_a_result: Sessions shorten. Burnout reports decline.
choice_b_result: Productivity metrics stay strong. Human costs stay invisible.

title: Where to Build the Data Center
body_text: Site A runs mostly on solar. Energy is cheap and clean - but water is scarce. Cooling will compete with agriculture. Site B has abundant water and existing cooling infrastructure. But the grid relies heavily on coal and gas.
choice_a_result: Emissions stay low. Water usage becomes a bottleneck.
choice_b_flavor: We optimize for reliability and scale.
choice_b_result: The system scales smoothly. Environmental scrutiny grows.

title: Cooling vs. Capability
body_text: The new model runs hotter. To keep performance, we need more cooling - more power, more water. Or we cap performance.
choice_a_result: Performance holds. Operating costs and resource use rise.
choice_b_result: Resource use stabilizes. Model growth plateaus.

title: The Supplier Question
body_text: Some of our critical components come from high-risk supply chains. Rare earths. Specialty chips. Cooling materials. Subcontractors flagged for unsafe labor conditions and forced overtime. We can switch to audited suppliers. But it will cost more.
choice_a_result: Supply chains become cleaner. Expansion slows and costs rise.
choice_b_result: Hardware stays cheap. Ethical risk remains embedded.

title: The Carbon Bill
body_text: Our systems don’t just consume electricity. They consume it at scale: data centers, cooling, redundancy. In some regions, that now includes carbon pricing. Every megawatt-hour has a cost and an emissions tag. We can keep operating the same way. Or we can reduce the most energy-intensive workloads. Either way, the bill doesn’t go away.
choice_a_flavor: We treat it as operating expense.
choice_a_result: Development continues uninterrupted. Margins quietly shrink.
choice_b_flavor: We cut where it hurts most.
choice_b_result: Emissions fall. Some teams lose their favorite models.

title: Who Gets Priority?
body_text: When capacity is tight, we prioritize workload. Right now, it’s whoever pays most. We could reserve capacity for public or safety-critical uses. Or keep it purely commercial.
choice_a_result: Essential services remain stable. Revenue opportunities shrink.
choice_b_result: Revenue is maximized. Access becomes uneven.

title: Who Pays the Infrastructure Cost?
body_text: Data centers don’t just use resources. They reshape local economies. Property prices near our sites have risen. Water and energy costs followed. Small businesses are being pushed out. We can contribute to local infrastructure. Or treat this as outside our responsibility. The market won’t correct this on its own.
choice_a_result: Local backlash softens. Expansion becomes more expensive.
choice_b_result: Margins stay strong. Social tension builds around your sites.

title: The Rebound Effect
body_text: Our efficiency work paid off. Energy per request is down. Costs dropped. Usage didn’t just grow. It exploded. Because the system is cheaper and faster, people use it more. For things they wouldn’t have used it for before. Total energy use is now higher than before the optimization. This is just what happens when something gets better.
choice_a_result: Total resource use stabilizes. Customers accuse you of artificial scarcity.
choice_b_result: Adoption surges. Infrastructure strain accelerates again.
